items.title: Type error: FetcherParams.variables declared as string but actually passed as object
Older NPMs (@apollographql/graphql-language-service-utils)
items.body:
Hi,

Is the MIT License in this repo meant to apply to the (5) NPM versions of this package here: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@apollographql/graphql-language-service-utils/v/2.0.2?  

I don't see any license info for the above package, though the package.json points here for issues (https://github.com/graphql/graphql-language-service/issues), which in turn points to this repo (on the README).

Same question for these NPM's - @apollographql/graphql-language-service-parser, @apollographql/graphql-language-service-types, and @apollographql/graphql-language-service-interface.  Does the MIT License apply to these NPMs too?

Thanks,
Ariel

items.title: regressions in variables completion
items.body:
`getAutocompleteSuggestions` was not updated to handle the parser fix for non-null list types, so variable completion was not working at all. we need to handle non-null list types, otherwise completion was not working. this would have impacted `graphiql`, `codemirror-graphql`, `monaco-graphql`, as well as the language server.

related to #1565 which was fixed for validation

addressed in #1616 for the next minor version for `graphql-config@3` without watchman, however I'd like to patch the fix in a quick PR for for folks still using watchman and `graphql-config@2`

items.title: Discussion:  How to take advantage of custom Scalar URLs
items.body:
GraphQL supports custom Scalar URLs. (See https://github.com/graphql/graphql-js/pull/2276). 

GraphiQL and the LSP could take advantage of it by supporting specific URLs through code completion and/or client side validation and probably more.

This is an Issue to get this conversation started.

items.title: regressions in variable validation
items.body:
Hey there, 

First off, thanks for making Graphiql! It's great!

I am getting an error similar to the one described in this issue: https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/issues/1308


Here's the query I have in the inspector: 
```
{
  sequences{
    pageSize
    pageNumber
    results {
      size
      sequenceFeatures {
        start
        end
        name
      }
    }
  }
}

{
  seq
}
```

And here are the errors: 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2730609/83463527-216fb100-a423-11ea-9943-d05ff0186862.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2730609/83463541-2df40980-a423-11ea-9452-212f43770d2f.png)


I believe this is because the logic passing the `highlightNode` into the `getLocation` function is faulty: 

```
      const highlightNode =
      node.kind !== 'Variable' && 'name' in node
        ? node.name
        : 'variable' in node
        ? node.variable
        : node;
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2730609/83464520-f3d83700-a425-11ea-9289-d37d2d1c4c23.png)

As you can see in the above image, `node.name` is undefined yet `'name' in node` still === true. This causes `undefined` to be passed to `getLocation` on line 137: ` const highlightLoc = getLocation(highlightNode);` 

In the past that code used to look like: 

```
  return error.nodes.map(node => {
    const highlightNode =
      node.kind !== 'Variable' && node.name
        ? node.name
        : node.variable
        ? node.variable
        : node;
```

But got converted in this PR https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/pull/957 to look like:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2730609/83464307-52e97c00-a425-11ea-95b9-cc47f85c0281.png)

I am going to make a PR to fix this specific issue where the `xxx in xxx` syntax is being used incorrectly.  I think it someone on the graphiql team should look at all the places that got changed to use the `xxx in xxx` syntax that might now break. 

Thanks!


P.S. In case it wasn't clearn, once I made the change I described above locally, the error I was seeing went away and graphiql resumed working properly again

items.title: monaco-graphql interfaces default to any
items.body:
## expected behaviour

`monaco.languages.graphql` module should be available, and it's user-facing interfaces should have replete types as defined in `packages/monaco-graphql/src/monaco.d.ts`.

## actual behavior

`monaco.languages.graphql` module interfaces are present, but all typed with `any`

## steps to reproduce

1. pull down the latest master of the repo
2. see everything in `packages/monaco-graphql` that refers to  `monaco.languages.graphql` is half working, where types/interfaces function params/etc are all any
3. then, you can reproduce in the `examples/monaco-graphql-webpack` example, which also uses these interfaces

## context

this api pattern was borrowed from other monaco modes, such as `monaco-json` or `monaco-yaml`

CC @cshaver @rebornix

items.title: onEditVariables is not triggered on first render

milestone.title: graphiql@1.0.0
milestone.description: GraphiQL is in feature freeze state until plugin API is introduced

items.body:
I'm trying to use `<GraphiQL>` as a controlled component, with a global redux store.

- In `graphiql@1.0.0-alpha.8`, `onEditVariables` is not triggered on the first render. It works fine in `graphiql@0.17.5`. 

I noticed that in 1.x, VariableEditor ignores change events till the first `componentDidUpdate` https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/blob/ce926bb7ab1e6fbf978ec53a0449c33869073c7d/packages/graphiql/src/components/VariableEditor.tsx#L62  I guess `ignoreChangeEvent` should be initialized to false

- Also both versions do not debounce `onEditVariables`, whereas `onEditQuery` seems to be debounced. 

Happy to contribute/raise a PR for this.

items.title: Bad type definition files in alpha release

milestone.title: graphiql@1.0.0
milestone.description: GraphiQL is in feature freeze state until plugin API is introduced

items.body:
The `.d.ts` files in the alpha release contains some bad imports, stemming from the package-relative imports like https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/blob/ce926bb7ab1e6fbf978ec53a0449c33869073c7d/packages/graphiql/src/components/QueryEditor.tsx#L15

A couple were fixed in https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/pull/1487, but there are a few more in the repo.

You likely don't want to set baseUrl [here](https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/blob/ce926bb7ab1e6fbf978ec53a0449c33869073c7d/packages/graphiql/tsconfig.json#L8), as that is what allows those imports during type checking of this project, but not in the published package. Although I haven't looked at what impact that will have on the rest of the build.

items.title: GraphiQL 2.0.0 beta Roadmap (monaco, redesign and plugin API!)
items.body:
Though the meta issue #983 summarizes all work that the new GraphiQL depends on, this issue is a roadmap for features that are GraphiQL *only*.


### `0.x.y`
- [x] e2e harness with Cypress and a starting suite
- [x] move from browserify to webpack build, improve webpack supprot with example configs
- [x] increase unit test coverage
- [x] numerous bugfixes
- [ ] backport a more IE compatible release, perhaps?
- [ ] e2e harness with Cypress and a nice suite to start with

### `2.0.0-beta`
- [ ] #977 - full i18next!
- [X] #967 - full accessibility!
- [X] #1107 - React 16, drop support for React 15
- [X] #1204 - support GraphQL 15
- [ ] interfaces implementing interfaces
- [ ] remote scalar support for completion
- [ ] #1359 - migrate to using React context, or another state management strategy
- [ ] React 16! Use deprecated class methods for now
- [ ] Get smarter with a core react context, provide `useGraphQLContext` hook, maybe with parsing and visitors/ast?
- [ ] Expose events interface to use internally and via plugins via `useReducer`, etc?
- [ ] Convert several smaller components to implement the hooks interface, use for existing functional components
- [ ] Begin with a 'plugins' array prop that renders Components that use context/reducer events and/or FCs that use hooks interface
- [ ] Adopt new monaco language mode, stabilize
- [ ] keymap/command customization to allow previous (sublime based) keymap, or new vscode-oriented keymap, or per-shortcut customization. Default keymap should have parity with last 0.x.y release?
- [ ] mostly stable API
- [ ] render middlewares
- [ ] full monaco support

items.title: Create a useable GraphQL Monaco Mode and Example
items.body:
We are working towards a stable `graphql-monaco` that will become a part of the official, stable GraphiQL reference implementation, in place of our project `codemirror-graphql`.

## Reasoning
The primary reasoning is that monaco is more closely aligned with the LSP spec, reducing many redundancies in the rest of our ide language service ecosystem. The effort of maintaining and introducing new language and editor features to GraphiQL and other browser/electron based IDEs will be significantly reduced.

What's more, users will have a great time with the vscode-like experience and built-in features. This will make it much easier for plugin authors to provide their own diagnostics (aka linting/validation), completion (aka hinting/autocompletion/intellisense), schema loaders, code helpers, command palette shortcuts, and many more options!  

## Design Notes

None of these will be dependent on react of course, as is also the case with `codemirror-graphql`. For example, altair project uses `codemirror-graphql` with angular! This is what we want to enable with `monaco-graphql` as wel, so implementations using vue, vanilla js, even older DOM manipulation frameworks are able to use this.

It will of course implement our underling GraphQL language service as other monaco modes do, so we will want to make PRs to modify/enhance the LSP and interfaces as needed. These will be ported from the current mega draft PR.

## Monaco GraphQL and examples
- `packages/monaco-graphql` (new) 
- `examples/monaco-amd-example` (new) - using amd/requirejs
- `examples/monaco-webpack-example` (new) 

### Work in Progress:

- **Draft PR** (#1421) - following monaco-json closely. This is the one that will become the actual monaco service.
- [Proof of Concept (POC) Branch](https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/tree/monaco-test/packages/monaco-graphql/src) - implements monaco using anti-patterns, but successfully achieves completion, diagnostics, popovers without instantiating the LSP class or using webworkers which is a requirement (this is what the draft PR above does). Uses underlying LSP functions the class uses, rather than the full class, similar to what `codemirror-graphql` does. This is meant to be for reference, just to see the familiar LS <> Monaco compatibility layer.
	- [demo code](https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/tree/monaco-test/packages/graphiql-examples/monaco-graphql-test)
    - [live demo](https://graphiql-monaco-mode-example.netlify.com/)
    - older [react POC](https://github.com/acao/graphiql-1-poc-monaco/tree/master/src) and [demo](https://graphiql-1-poc.netlify.com/)

### TODO


- [x] (in progress, some methods work but not full LSP class) launch language service(s) in webworker(s) (see: monaco-json, monaco-typescript, etc)
- [x] operation diagnostics
- [ ] (in progress) operation completion 
- [ ] (in progress) Port GraphQL cache for web and server usage, remove runtime dependent features and replace with config options
- [x] re-register default graphql language with our own version
- [ ] operation references/definition support (via LS class)
- [ ] variables JSON completion/diagnostics/declarations etc (dynamically define json schema, so much simpler than with codemirror!)

items.title: GraphiQL `onEditQuery` is called without query argument after TypeScript migration
items.body:
I'm updating our installation of graphiql to `1.0.0-alpha.1`, and thanks to the new TypeScript types (🎉) I was was really quickly made aware that the type signature of the function passed to `GraphiQL` as the `onEditQuery` prop has changed:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2136754/77381603-947dec80-6d3b-11ea-885f-2249f8cef858.png)

This breaks our usage of graphiql-explorer. (see example setup  which uses `onEditQuery` https://github.com/OneGraph/graphiql-explorer-example/blob/master/src/App.js#L189)

It looks like this change was made in the [recent TypeScript migration](https://github.com/ryan-m-walker/graphiql/commit/2de0f44d3851a76b070417a48c69ff4050f8674b#diff-d9161d32c36caed395ae91f2856c023eL948).

I understand that this prop is likely going to be deprecated in the new API per #1165, but it looks to me like this change was unintentional (`onEditQuery` is unchanged in the README, and per https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/pull/1242#issue-364380842 that this should have minimal production changes).

items.title: [CLI]: Recommend matching commands
items.body: `yargs` arg-parser library provides `recommendCommands()` function as part of the API to suggest the closest match to an unknown command passed in.

items.title: [CLI]: Handle unrecognized commands
items.body: `yargs` arg-parser library comes shipped with a `strict()` method as part of the API to handle unrecognized commands. We can leverage it to show up an appropriate message if the user passes in an unknown command.

items.title: Proposal: More LSP friendly package names
items.body:
We're working to further LSP-ify our language services and server in preparation for monaco and an improved LSP interface and experience (see: https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/project/6).

(**Edit:** Revised, as npm will not allow us to publish both `graphql-language-service` and `graphql-languageservice`)

Overall, we need `graphql-language-service` to refer to a runtime agnostic service, and for the CLI to become another package with an explicit name, such as `graphql-language-service-cli`

## Deprecating the binary

To transition users from the `graphql` bin included in `graphql-language-service`, the new `graphql-language-service` package will include a bin temporarily that just stderrs to install the new cli package, as I've seen webpack do.

## CLI Usage Notes

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1368727/82156613-25f47100-984a-11ea-93f5-225d39fcf80d.png)

The GraphQL Language Service has taken off in terms of usage, however by comparison to our other packages in the monorepo it's still the least installed. That said, it's often installed as a global bin, so usage will be different.

Also, to note, I've seen a few implementations of it that bundle the packaged bin manually with whatever IDE plugin that uses it, as their actual IDE plugin code is written in python, lua, etc.

So, a significant amount of users could be impacted by this.

## Renaming the bin

Another consideration is renaming the bin itself. `graphql` bin path is being used by `graphql-cli`, which we may end up using/reccomending for scaffolding plugins.  After working with a wide range of IDE extension developers (not just vscode devs), `LSP` is very descriptive.

So, I reccomend changing the bin as such:

`graphql` => `graphql-lsp`

items.title: confiig(husky): support for `deps` commit msg type
items.body:
The pre-commit hook doesn't allow to use `deps` for the commit type message. It would be great if it allows such convention.

```
husky > pre-commit (node v12.13.0)
  ✔ Preparing...
  ✔ Running tasks...
  ✔ Applying modifications...
  ✔ Cleaning up...
husky > commit-msg (node v12.13.0)
⧗   input: deps(service): upgraded yargs
✖   type must be one of [build, chore, ci, docs, feat, fix, improvement, perf, refactor, revert, style, test] [type-enum]

✖   found 1 problems, 0 warnings
ⓘ   Get help: https://github.com/conventional-changelog/commitlint/#what-is-commitlint
```

items.title: Unable to build schema using buildSchema
items.body:
My schema end point returns this string

"Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the if argument is true"
directive @include(
    "Included when true."
    if: Boolean!
  ) on FIELD | FRAGMENT_SPREAD | INLINE_FRAGMENT

"Directs the executor to skip this field or fragment when the if 'argument is true."
directive @skip(
    "Skipped when true."
    if: Boolean!
  ) on FIELD | FRAGMENT_SPREAD | INLINE_FRAGMENT

"Marks the field or enum value as deprecated"
directive @deprecated(
    "The reason for the deprecation"
    reason: String = "No longer supported"
  ) on FIELD_DEFINITION | ENUM_VALUE

union streamItem = Ad | Content | EditorialPackage | EntityCard
.
.
.
.


when trying to build schema object using

`
const buildSchema  = require('graphql').buildSchema;
const schema = buildSchema(schemaString);      
`


i am getting this error

`{ GraphQLError: Syntax Error GraphQL request (5:1) Unexpected String "Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true"
4: 
5: "Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the if argument is true"
   ^
6: directive @include(
    at syntaxError (/node_modules/graphql/error/syntaxError.js:31:15)
    at unexpected (/node_modules/graphql/language/parser.js:996:33)
    at parseDefinition (/node_modules/graphql/language/parser.js:155:9)
    at parseDocument (node_modules/graphql/language/parser.js:109:22)
    at parse (/node_modules/graphql/language/parser.js:46:10)
    at buildSchema (/node_modules/graphql/utilities/buildASTSchema.js:469:43)
    at getRequest.then (/src/schema.js:42:32)
    at <anonymous>
    at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:188:7)
  message: 'Syntax Error GraphQL request (5:1) Unexpected String "Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true"\n\n4: \n5: "Directs the executor to include this field or fragment only when the `if` argument is true"\n   ^\n6: directive @include(\n',
  locations: [ { line: 5, column: 1 } ],
  path: undefined }

`

this is my package json
`
  "dependencies": {
    "env": "0.0.2",
    "express": "4.17.1",
    "express-graphql": "0.9.0",
    "graphql": "14.6.0",
    "path": "0.12.7"
  },


Are comments invalid for directives or is there a bug with `buildSchema`

items.title: minor css linting
items.body:
The https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/blob/master/packages/graphiql/src/css/app.css file has `margin: none;` at line 369, but `none` is not a valid option per https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/margin. At line 25 there is an example of using `margin: 0;` which may be an appropriate replacement.

Additionally on line 437 there is `text-overflow: -o-ellipsis-lastline;` which might be appropriate to update to `text-overflow: ellipsis;` per https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/text-overflow.

There is a usage of `box-orient` on line 428 which is marked as having been superceeded: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/box-orient and https://caniuse.com/#search=box-orient.

There is a ussage of `line-clamp` that might be worth a second glance per https://caniuse.com/#search=line-clamp.

items.title: [graphql-language-service]: TypeError [ERR_INVALID_ARG_TYPE]: The "chunk" argument must be one of type string or Buffer. Received type object
items.body:
`graph-language-service` doesn't return an error message that shows what you need to do.

## how to reproduce
Run one of the following commands in the root of package `graphql-language-service`, then you got the same error message as the title.
`bin/graphql.js autocomplete --text foo --schemaPath ...`
`bin/graphql.js outline --text foo`
`bin/graphql.js validate --text foo --schemaPath ...`
(Before running these scripts, you need to run `yarn build` in advance.)

## cause
`error` given at https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/blob/917c3931634cf27eb31a0383ff7c15ffd902d221/packages/graphql-language-service/src/client.ts#L105
or
https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/blob/917c3931634cf27eb31a0383ff7c15ffd902d221/packages/graphql-language-service/src/client.ts#L134
or
https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/blob/917c3931634cf27eb31a0383ff7c15ffd902d221/packages/graphql-language-service/src/client.ts#L148
is actually type object, though `process.stderr.write` method doesn't allow for type object. Therefore, the method throws an error.

items.title: buildClientSchema, introspection result missing interfaces
items.body:
I'm trying to use graphql's `buildClientSchema` to generate a schema that can be used for mocking/testing components as [seen in this link.][0]

This error is thrown and I'm un-sure how to proceed,
```
Error: Introspection result missing interfaces
```
To try and simplify the situation, I've modified the schema slightly for now to define one type.
```javascript
jsonSchema.__schema.types = [ jsonSchema.__schema.types[0] ];
const schema = buildClientSchema( jsonSchema );
```
and the following is the error result,
```
Error: Introspection result missing interfaces:
{ kind: "OBJECT", name: "Query", possibleTypes: null }
```
The service originating the schema and the sources calling buildClientSchema are using graphql version 14.5.8.

I would be glad if someone would tell what I'm doing wrong and would welcome any solution.

[0]: https://www.apollographql.com/docs/graphql-tools/mocking/#mocking-a-schema-using-introspection

items.body:
@acao @benjie Took a long long time than I initially anticipated but I finally released `graphql@15.0.0-rc1`.
It includes a number of small breaking changes:
https://github.com/graphql/graphql-js/releases/tag/v15.0.0-alpha.1
https://github.com/graphql/graphql-js/releases/tag/v15.0.0-alpha.2
https://github.com/graphql/graphql-js/releases/tag/v15.0.0-rc.1

Can you please test it with packages in this repo so I can release `15.0.0` without worrying about breaking GraphiQL?

Note: It doesn't yet include two-stage introspection that I currently working on and will add in the next release since it's not a breaking change.

items.title: (question) How can i get the schema after it has been fetched
items.body:
I'm trying to add [graphiql-explorer](https://github.com/OneGraph/graphiql-explorer/) to a project but it requires the graphql schema (*of type GraphQLSchema*) that i guess is somewhere inside this library.  

I've found that the state of the `GraphiQL` contains that but i can't seem to get it out using:  
```jsx
<GraphiQL ref={c => { console.log(c ? c.state.schema : c) }} fetcher={fetcher}>
// Console output: undefined
```
The wired thing is if i log just the reference (`c`) i can click to `.state.schema` and see the schema???  

I've tried a lot of things but the only solution seems to be fetching the schema separately and putting it inside the GraphiQL and the GraphiQL explorer but i have no idea of how to do that.

items.title: Automated conventional commits wants us to bump GraphiQL to 1.0.0
items.body:
@benjie we haven't even gotten to #1165  yet, however already conventional commits angular preset (the lerna default) wants this:

this is what i get upon running `lerna publish --no-git-tag-version --no-push --registry=fake` locally, for a dry run essentially. I usually run it with `lerna publish --otp <otp>` if I want to actually publish. It of course inherits the underlying lerna.json args which include `conventionalCommits`, etc.
![Screen Shot 2019-12-28 at 3 51 43 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1368727/71549362-2028ec80-298a-11ea-9b88-adfd071df3d3.png)

because of the commit with the breaking change flag #1106 

![Screen Shot 2019-12-28 at 3 56 27 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1368727/71549405-bc52f380-298a-11ea-9630-08793b9a5248.png)

(both of these were simulated in a dry run)

before, `lerna publish` has been perfect for automatically bumping versions, but it was this use of the `BREAKING CHANGE` footer prefix in the react 15 support drop commit that is forcing a major version bump. 

This tool has been to our great advantage, so that we don't have to go around and manually reference the latest interdependent versions in every release like before. That is what `lerna publish` already does, by running both version and publish in the same command, allowing the interdependent.

We can just revise the commit log to remove that entry and only use that for the next stable release as we have planned, *or* (more complex) we implement our own conventional changelog preset, and configure lerna to use that which would be a bit more complex but is also certainly possible. (note: we can use lerna.json `extends`, I don't think it's in documentation but its in the code, allows you to load CJS configs for lerna commands for example (different environments, etc)

items.body:
GraphQL newbie here, following the notes in readme:
> ### How To Setup/Implement GraphiQL
> The GraphiQL Readme explains some of the ways to implement GraphiQL, and we also have the examples directory as well!

Trying out the `graphql-cdn` example:

```sh
$ git clone https://github.com/graphql/graphiql.git
$ cd graphiql/packages/examples/graphiql-cdn
$ yarn install
...
$ yarn build-demo
yarn run v1.19.2
$ cp ../../graphiql/graphiql.js ../../graphiql/graphiql.css ../../graphiql/resources/renderExample.js .
cp: cannot stat '../../graphiql/graphiql.js': No such file or directory
cp: cannot stat '../../graphiql/graphiql.css': No such file or directory
error Command failed with exit code 1.
info Visit https://yarnpkg.com/en/docs/cli/run for documentation about this command.

Have I missed some crucial step here? Or is the example broken?

```
Simple client app is just trying to mount the GraphiQL component to the entire page:
```
$ cat client/main.jsx 
import GraphiQL from 'graphiql'
import React from 'react'
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom'

import 'graphiql/graphiql.css'

function fetchGraphQL(params) {
  const url = window.location.origin + '/gql'
  const fetchParams = {
    method: 'post',
    headers: {'Content-Type': 'application/json'},
    body: JSON.stringify(params),
  }
  return window.fetch(url, fetchParams)
    .then(response => response.json())
}

const app = <GraphiQL fetcher={fetchGraphQL} />
ReactDOM.render(app, document.body);
```

items.title: Windows: Running yarn tests reports trying to use "printf"
items.body: Running the https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#getting-started steps on windows 10 (command line running as admin) I get an error showing at the end of the run about `printf` which doesn't exist on windows. Not sure whats throwing it as the `yarn tests` command chains a bunch of stuff together so I'll run them individual and see if I can narrow it down.

items.title: Windows: Running tests reports errors with line endings
items.body:
Following the instructions on https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#getting-started results in line ending issue being reported when running the test (yarn test):

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1674590/69888294-f1641b80-12e2-11ea-9a26-561f19570748.png)

Seems by default git for windows will checkout files and convert them to CRLF line endings rather than LF as everyone else is using.

Initially I can fix this by running `npm run lint-fix` but I had to find that and google about it to know I could do it, better to not have to have Windows devs run that each time.

Seems a new rule is needed to be added to a currently non-existant file (.gitattributes) to overrule this setting when first checked out on windows machines.

https://eslint.org/docs/rules/linebreak-style#using-this-rule-with-version-control-systems

Alternative is to add something to the docs.

items.title: Build throws warnings originating in `graphql-language-service-interface`
Invalid aria prop `aria-description` in ToolbarButton
items.body:
#967 introduced a new warning:
```
Warning: Invalid aria prop `aria-description` on <button> tag. For details, see https://fb.me/invalid-aria-prop
    in button (created by ToolbarButton)
    in ToolbarButton (created by GraphiQL)
```
`aria-description` is not an official prop (but https://github.com/w3c/aria/issues/891 [re]started an attempt to include it).
Since there's already a `title`, I believe `aria-description` can be dropped without consequence.

items.title: Unable to prettify query variables input
items.body:
As a user it is really useful to prettify the input query/mutation/suscription. But AFAIK there's currently no way to prettify the query variables section.
If one follows the convention for mutations to receive a unique input field, it becomes cumbersome when a mutation has many arguments as one has to indent them manually.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11272260/67804231-540c9200-fa6d-11e9-8b46-07d17181c080.png)

I'd like to visualize the response json every time it gets updated.
Is there a way to hook into this? 
I expected to find a prop like `onResponseUpdate` (that receives the new response json), but can't find anything like that.

items.title: React duplicate key warning in QueryHistory component since 0.16.0
Broken minified build for graphiql 0.16.0
items.body:
Hi All,

The jsDelivr CDN distribution of GraphiQL seems broken at the moment.

I followed the official example at https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/blob/master/packages/examples/graphiql-cdn/index.html, and then changed the CDN URL from `./graphiql.js` to https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/graphiql/graphiql.min.js, which results in `Minified React error #130`.

Changing it to the full version ( https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/npm/graphiql/graphiql.js) seems to fix it.

Not sure if this issue belongs here, just something to note.
Thanks!

items.title: Feature request: Execute specific query or mutation
items.body: graphiql currently execute all queries or mutations in the editor. We have to comment it if we want to exclude it from execution. The would be a great feature if it allows us to run specific query (like DBMS client).

items.title: Results panel can be made inaccessible through resizing
items.body:
Playing around in graphiql today I hid the result frame to make some more room for the text editor window and then couldn't find a way to bring it back, this video can show what am talking about:

https://gfycat.com/playfulalarmedbird

As you can see, if you resize the result "frame" minimizing it all the way to the right, if you try to drag it back you will resize the entire browser window, there's also no button or other intuitive way of bringing the frame back, clicking on "run" should automatically bring the results frame back, or maybe adding a button to the top bar.

the only way to bring it back is by double-clicking inside the text editor frame, which is not very intuitive.

items.title: License for @apollographql/graphql-language-service-interface
items.body:
It seems like some packages and repos got moved around. Is [@apollographql/graphql-language-service-interface](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@apollographql/graphql-language-service-interface) published from this repo?

If so, can we please publish the latest version for `interface`, `parser`, `types` and `utils`, as these all contain valid licenses, but [2.0.2](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@apollographql/graphql-language-service-interface/v/2.0.2) does not.

If not, can you direct me to the right repo?

items.title: Permalinks (share URL link)?
items.body:
According to #7, queries in URL are a feature of GraphiQL and I've seen them in the wild, for example, in the [Pokemon API](https://graphql-pokemon.now.sh/?query=%7B%0A%20%20pokemon(name%3A%20%22Pikachu%22)%20%7B%0A%20%20%20%20id%0A%20%20%7D%0A%7D). But I've also encountered several GraphiQL installations that don't have queries in URLs, e.g., [Shopify's](https://help.shopify.com/en/api/storefront-graphiql), [MongoDB todo list](https://todo-mongo-graphql-server.herokuapp.com/), etc.

In https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/issues/703, it is mentioned that it's supported via graphiql-rails but is that the only way?

I'm just asking for clarification. On the APIs that support the `?query=` URL links, I find it a bit suspicious that it's `?` and not `#` (I'd imagine queries working purely client-side).

That link is broken.

items.title: schema not showing - aspnet core
Publish a new release of graphiql

There are a few interesting commits that fix annoying problems in our case. Notably https://github.com/graphql/graphiql/commit/ca226ee6e299f253364b9e66c723c1edff620246, that makes graphiql behave well if integrated within other react components that appear/disappear.

Personally I consider it worth a release. Looking forward to getting the next package :-)

Best regards.

items.title: Publish New Release of graphql-language-service-* packages
items.body: It would be awesome if we could get a new release of the `graphql-language-service-*` packages. Even if it is a prerelease or alpha version. Looks like the previous release was over a year ago.

items.title: Can't set endpoint in graphiql
items.body:
Hello. I am completely new to GraphQL. I just saw this [video here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=broQmxQAMjM&t=695s) where GraphiQL is shown. I found the link to get GraphiQL running, but anything above the horizontal gray bar (with the play button and the Docs button) was completely missing. I could not specify the endpoint at all. I would like to do what is shown in the video, but I can't set the endpoint and therefore all queries that I type are pointless.

And yea, docs also seem to not work.

items.title: Migrate from mocha to jest
items.body: The graphiql package is using `jest` for testing, while the other packages use mocha. IMO the jest testing experience is much better than mocha with great built in support for code coverage, mocking, watch functionality, etc. If there is interest in migrating test suites from mocha to jest, I would be happy to help out.

items.title: Potential bug: __typename as a hint suggestion
items.body: Seems that `graphql-language-service-interface` 2.0.x is appending `__typename` as a hint suggestion everywhere by default now. This wasn't the case a month or so ago.

items.title: GraphiQL browser underlines nested lists in a query, but the query still works
GraphiQL live demo doesn't show docs
items.body:
[GraphiQL live demo](http://graphql.org/swapi-graphql) shows only a loading indicator but not docs when I click docs at the top right.

The browser I've used is the version of 75.0.3770.100 of chrome and I've got the following error messages in the browser console.

`GET https://graphql.org/schema.js net::ERR_ABORTED 404`

`Uncaught ReferenceError: Schema is not defined
    at graphQLFetcher (swapi-graphql:86)
    at t.value (graphiql.min.js:1)
    at t.value (graphiql.min.js:1)
    at e.notifyAll (react-dom.min.js:12)

items.title: Add vim mode
items.body:
It would be nice if you can run some simplified version of vim inside the editor. Specifically I wish I could do `di{` to delete inside `{}` brackets. But some other vim features would be very nice to have too.

Perhaps [neovim](https://neovim.io) could be embedded to serve this purpose.

items.title: Check mark is not visible in select lists
items.body:
Check mark is not visible when an item is selected from a select list in the toolbar.

How it looks like:
![Screenshot_2019-07-05 GraphiQL(1)](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32361480/60720956-05267400-9f35-11e9-914d-bda1f34f57e8.png)

How it should look like:
![Screenshot_2019-07-05 GraphiQL](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32361480/60720991-26876000-9f35-11e9-8e2a-81ec4241e8ae.png)

items.title: Prettify Query shortcut (Shift-Ctrl-P) non-functional for Firefox users
items.body:
Trying GraphiQL for the first time, the default message has a helpful line:

```
Prettify Query:  Shift-Ctrl-P (or press the prettify button above)
```

Unfortunately, at least with Firefox that won't work, as Firefox has a hard coded key binding for "Shift-Ctrl-P".  Instead it just brings up a Private Browsing window, and the key combination doesn't make it through to the GraphiQL window:

![FF1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/406299/60685700-e483fd00-9ee7-11e9-9117-570285b92baf.png)

Firefox doesn't natively have any ability to change key bindings either (ugh).  There is a "Saka Key" extension which can apparently allow for key binding changes, but that seems pretty non-optimal.

Is there a way to change the GraphiQL key binding instead?

items.title: Example setup documentation regression
items.body:
When I try to run the example I get stuck on a `Loading..` screen with error: 
```
Refused to apply style from 'http://localhost:49909/graphiql.css' because its MIME type ('text/html') is not a supported stylesheet MIME type, and strict MIME checking is enabled.
Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 404 (Not Found)
```

Here are the commands I ran:
```
graphiql:
	npm install
	yarn install
	npm build
graphiql/packages/graphiql:
	npm install
	npm run build
graphiql/packages/graphiql/example:
	npm install
	npm start
```

items.title: Empty tooltip on results
items.body:
In results viewer, hovering over query results always shows an empty tooltip:
![Screen Shot 2019-06-20 at 4 29 40 PM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1368727/59879848-ab8d4980-9379-11e9-82d5-b810245f3339.png)

Additionally, if you include an image in the query, then the image preview works, however it appears when you hover over _all_ fields, and continues to appear even when you remove the fields with images. I haven't tried with multiple image fields, but I'm guessing it might not work well in that context either.

items.title: Re-introduce browserslist for graphiql repository.
items.body: .browserslistrc is more ideal. Should we drop vendor prefixes without a minor version bump?

items.title: Can the Documentation Explorer show directives?
items.body: I wrote a custom directive to authenticate parts of my graph, a little something like this: ```.graphql type Query { publicField: String! user(id: String!): User @isLoggedIn } ``` But when I browse the graph in the GraphiQL Documentation Explorer, I don't see any reference to this directive (at this level or nested within either the `user` field or `User` entity's documentation): This seems like it could be a useful feature, but I'd love to know if I'm missing something and it either already exists, or would cause issues that I don't understand! And I'm using `graphiql: "0.13.0"`. Let me know if there's other info I can provide!

items.title: Discussion: Modernization
items.body:
_This is merely a rough draft for a foundation of discussion_

## Design Criteria
Before getting into design details I think it's worth while to provide a definition of graphiql in order to provide context for this design; **graphiql**: An in-browser IDE for exploring GraphQL.

This definition means that graphiql can be split into two components: **ui** and **business logic** (i.e. http req/resp). 
The primary use case for graphiql (in my opinion) is for development/testing of a graphql service, which means assuming an **offline** environment is not too far of a reach.

Now, equipped with the criteria of providing a **ui**, **business logic** (http req/resp), and an **offline experience**, what follows is my proposal for redesign. (**Note**: the current design does satisfy all of these criteria)

## Design Proposal

### Web Component
In line with the current design, a [web component](https://www.webcomponents.org/introduction) (built with [StencilJS](https://stenciljs.com)?) will be provided to allow for embedding of graphiql into another project. The exported component need not be a web component, per se, it could still just be a React component, but a web component would be more framework neutral.

One major difference will be that the component must be provided an http client object instead of the fetcher function. A default client will also be exported.

### Default Environment
A default graphiql app would be hosted on github pages at https://graphiql.github.io.
The main ui of the site will be the graphiql component but combined with a form input field to change the graphql http endpoint. The schema would then be loaded from this endpoint through introspection.

```html
<form>
  Endpoint: <input typ="text" name="endpoint"/>
</form>

<graphiql endpoint=endpoint></graphiql> <!-- Web component -->
<!-- Have a script tag update endpoint value and the web component should rerender itself -->
```

To support offline development, instead of requiring developers to spin up there own server just to display graphiql, a [Service Worker](https://developers.google.com/web/fundamentals/primers/service-workers/) will be registered to cache all assets associated with graphiql.github.io.

items.title: 🚀 IDE Monorepo or bust! 🚀
items.body:
So, as per discussions amongst the GraphiQL Maintainers Team, we are about to move towards a monorepo pattern, whereupon:

- `graphiql`
- `graphql-language-service` - a monorepo with:
  - `graphql-language-service-parser`
  - `graphql-language-service-server`
  - `graphql-language-service-interface`
  - `graphql-language-service-types`
  - `graphql-language-service-utils`
- `codemirror-graphql`

Will all be combined into this repo, as a lerna + yarn workspaces monorepo, living side by side.

We will migrate all git and github history from the two projects to this repository, and `graphiql` will be the reference implementation for the official GraphQL Foundation-owned IDE ecosystem.

Package names will be retained, however we are likely going to bump the next major versions of all of them to `14.0`, to match `graphql-js`.

This is all precedent to the forthcoming `graphiql` 1.0 effort (maybe graphiql 14.0 ?), though discussions and deliberation will continue concurrently to this effort.

Most of this was discussed at the last GraphiQL WG meeting, however if anyone has concerns, we can deliberate on it again.

We will provide instructions on how to port your PRs from other repositories to this one.

Here is a preview, currently with just `graphiql` and `codemirror-graphql`:
https://github.com/acao/graphiql/tree/ide-monorepo
